sec.title: Introduction:
sec.p: Musculoskeletal pain and opioid misuse frequently co-occur.

sec.title: Review of the Literature:
sec.p: The U.S. Preventive Services Task Force calls for all healthcare providers to be trained to screen for misuse and/or opioid use disorder. The purpose of this study was to develop and implement an opioid misuse training program that could be used by physical therapists.

sec.title: Subjects:
sec.p: Thirteen practicing physical therapists were invited to participate in a curriculum development project.

sec.title: Methods:
sec.p: Using the Curriculum Framework, a collaborative learning approach was used to develop an opioid misuse training program and training manual for physical therapists. Four training sessions were provided virtually every 2 weeks. Topics included an introduction to the opioid crisis, screening, assessing and communicating with patients and with the health care team about opioid misuse. Each didactic session was followed by a participant feedback session where participants provided recommendations on improving the training content and their impressions on the barriers and facilitators to incorporating the training into practice. A companion training manual was created and sent to participants for comment. Participants were asked over email to describe whether and how they incorporated training materials into clinical practice during the training curriculum.

sec.title: Results:
sec.p: All participants attended sessions 1-3. Twelve (92.3%) attended the 4th session. Based on the participants’ feedback, training sessions were edited, and a companion training manual was finalized and distributed to each participant. After the 4th session, 9 (69.2%) participants reported using what they learned in the training. During the participant feedback sessions, participants regarded the training as important. Some participants expressed barriers to discussing opioids with patients and concerns about whether the training was within physical therapists’ scope of practice.

sec.title: Discussion and Conclusions:
sec.p: An iteratively developed training program for physical therapists to address opioid misuse was acceptable, feasible, and provided immediate practice change by most participants.
